The president and chief executive officer of Veeco Instruments Inc. (Nasdaq: VECO) , Christine B. Whitman, resigned after the Plainview company reported third quarter results lower than expected. She also gave up her position on the board but will continue as a consultant. Edward H. Braun, chairman of the board, will take over the chief executive's position and continue as president.

Veeco's anticipated sales for the third quarter were approximately $93 million, falling below expectations of $104 million. Earnings per share were announced as below 22 cents, approximately half for the same period last year. This came despite record orders for the quarter of approximately $175 million.

The company blamed lower sales and earnings on Veeco's acquisition of CVC, a competitor. The problem, they said, was delayed orders and shipments from data storage and specialty semiconductor customers. There were also problems with the company's ion beam deposition operations, which have been moved from Virginia to the company's headquarters in Plainview.
Veeco manufactures process equipment and metrology tools for the optical telecommunications, data storage, semiconductor and research markets.

Lake Success-based Pudgies Chicken Inc. agreed to be acquired by the parent company of Arthur Treacher's Fish and Chips. An IPO is planned. . . . 1-800-Flowers.com (Nasdaq: FLWS) announced that FlowersUSA, a national florist in Centerbrook, Conn., had agreed to turn over ownership of five disputed domain names. The Westbury floral and gift company sued FlowersUSA claiming trademark infringement, unfair competition, and deceptive trade practices. . . . Allied Business Intelligence Inc. of Oyster Bay has filed a lawsuit against Mindbranch Inc., formerly known as Publications Resource Group Inc., alleging a Mindbranch board member remains involved with an Allied Business Intelligence competitor. . . . Canon Inc. (N.Y.S.E.: CAJ) of Lake Success settled its intellectual property litigation against Nu-kote International Inc. Nu-kote can continue to market its 600 series of cartridges and continue to use its current packaging. . . . Computer Associates' new general manager for global marketing, Ken Fitzpatrick, was main speaker at the third anniversary celebration for the Long Island Software Technology Network in Great River.
